SoundWire Large System: 2-Load Dumbbell Topology Notes
NoteDetail
M_Cable characteristic impedance target50 Ω ± 10%.
R1Device Down topology: 10 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching. Add-In Card topology: 22 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching.
R2Device Down topology: 10 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching. Add-In Card topology: 22 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching.
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency9.6 MHz
SoundWire ports supportedPort #0, Port #1, Port #2, Port #3.
Length matching between CLK and DATA signals5.08 mm
CPU TX & RX timing register configurationFor total length < 1003.3 mm: [1] CLDS = 5 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period For total length ≥ 1003.3 mm: [1] CLDS = 9 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period Please refer to "Intel Smart Sound Technology ACPI Configuration" for further details on how to configure timing register. (BIOS Specification Doc#:  609917)
CPU buffer driver strength50 Ω, slew 11.
Device buffer driver strength & resistor combination1) Device buffer driver strength of 20 Ω ± 30% 2) Device series resistor of 68 Ω ± 5% Refer to section on "Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines" for resistor placement to achieve the recommended device drive impedance target.
Signal name/ listSNDW[0:3]_CLK, SNDW[0:3]_DATA.

SoundWire Large System: 3 to 4-Load Dumbbell Topology

SoundWire Large System: 3 to 4-Load Dumbbell Option 1 Topology Diagram
SoundWire Large System: 3 to 4-Load Dumbbell Option 2 Topology Diagram
SoundWire Large System: 3 to 4-Load Dumbbell Option 3 Topology Diagram
SoundWire Large System: 3 to 4-Load Dumbbell Topology Notes
NoteDetail
M_Cable_[1:2] characteristic impedance target50 Ω ± 10%.
R115 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching.
R215 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching.
Multiload supportThis topology supports up to 4 devices. For 3-Load topology, only device 2/ 3/ 4 can be removed.
Length ExtensionTotal length for 3-Load topology can be extended up to 520 mm by increase segment length: [1] M4 + M_cable1 = 300 mm [2] M5 = 300 mm
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency9.6 MHz
SoundWire ports supportedPort #0, Port #1, Port #2, Port #3.
Length matching between CLK and DATA signals5.08 mm
CPU TX & RX timing register configurationFor total length < 508 mm: [1] CLDS = 5 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period For total length ≥ 508 mm: [1] CLDS = 9 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period Please refer to "Intel Smart Sound Technology ACPI Configuration" for further details on how to configure timing register. (BIOS Specification Doc#:  609917)
CPU buffer driver strength50 Ω, slew 11.
Device buffer driver strength & resistor combination1) Device buffer driver strength of 20 Ω ± 30% 2) Device series resistor of 91 Ω ± 5% Refer to section on "Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines" for resistor placement to achieve the recommended device drive impedance target.

M_Cable_1 maximum length250 mm
Max allowable cable length between nearest device and furthest device from CPU300 mm
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).

Multiload supportThis topology supports up to 4 devices where device placements are interchangable.

[2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency12.288 MHz
SoundWire ports supported1 to 4-Load topology: Single-lane: Port #0, Port #1, Port #2, Port #3. 1-Load topology: Multi-lane: Port #2 (up to 3 data lane), Port #3 (up to 4 data lane).

[For Internal Validation] Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines

Description: In the topology section the device buffer strength target recommendations are different depending on the Topology and its configuration. If devices used do not have buffer strengths that match the target recommendations and do not have the ability to adjust the buffer strengths through software you can adjust the impedance via an external resistor (R1) in series near the device, between the device and processor. To determine R1 the formula is: R1=Device Buffer Impedance Target - Actual Device Buffer Impedance.

[For Internal Validation] SoundWire* Device Drive Impedance Adjustment
[For Internal Validation] Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines Notes
NoteDetail
M110 mm
R1R1 = Device Drive Impedance Target - Device Buffer Strength. For example: Device Drive Impedance Target = 80 Ω. Device Buffer Strength = 45 Ω. Then R1 = 80 Ω - 45 Ω = 35 Ω.

SPI0 Flash

SPI0 Flash 50MHz 1 to 4-Load Branch (Device Down) MAF Topology

SPI0 50MHz 1-Load MAF (Device Down) Topology Diagram
SPI0 50MHz 2-Load Branch MAF (Device Down) with 2 Flash Topology Diagram
SPI0 50MHz 2-Load Branch MAF (Device Down) with Flash and TPM Topology Diagram
SPI0 50MHz 3-Load Branch MAF (Device Down) Topology Diagram
SPI0 50MHz 4-Load Branch MAF (Device Down) Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 50MHz 1 to 4-Load Branch (Device Down) MAF Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1 & Flash 2: 50 MHz. TPM: 33 MHz.
Flash ProgrammerRequire additional isolation circuitry to protect CPU from back-feed voltage when connect to flash programmer.
R124 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 5.08 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R251 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 5.08 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from CPU to flash 1 or flash 2Length from CPU to flash 1 or flash 2: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 1[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.45 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6.5 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 2[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.25 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 14 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 9 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Minimum length, totalMin length between CPU to the closest end device = 30.48 mm.
Stuffing resistorIf one of devices is unstuffed (rework), treat it as (n -1)-Load topology thus place stuffing resistor as close as possible to the branch to avoid long stub length.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Signal name/ listSPI0_CLK, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_IO2, SPI0_IO3, SPI0_CS[0:1]# (for flash), SPI0_CS2# (for TPM)
Max Number of vias

NoteDetail

R251 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 5.08 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from CPU to flash 1 or flash 2Length from CPU to flash 1 or flash 2: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4
Minimum length, totalMin length between CPU to the closest end device = 30.48 mm.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 1[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.45 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6.5 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 2[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.25 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 14 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 9 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Stuffing resistorIf one of devices is unstuffed (rework), treat it as (n - 1)-Load topology thus place stuffing resistor as close as possible to the branch to avoid long stub length.
FET component criteriaRon < 4.5 Ω. Cin < 6 pF.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm

SPI0 Flash 50MHz 2 to 3-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR Topology

SPI0 2-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR Topology Diagram
SPI0 3-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR of Flash and TPM Topology Diagram
SPI0 3-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR of Flash Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 50MHz 2 to 3-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1 & Flash 2: 50 MHz. EC: 50MHz. TPM: 33 MHz.
Flash ProgrammerRequire additional isolation circuitry to protect CPU from back-feed voltage when connect to flash programmer.
EC and CPU branch requirementDelta between BO + M1 + M2 and M7 + M8 shall not exceed 25.4 mm.
Flash branch requirement, M3 + M4SPI branches of segment M3 + M4 need length matching within 2.54mm.
R1[1] DATA: 18 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 15.24 mm from the branch on SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3. [2] CLK: 24 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 15.24 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK.
R218 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R351 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Minimum length, total58.42 mm. Min length between CPU to the closest end device = 58.42 mm.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 1[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.45 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6.5 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 2[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.25 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 14 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 9 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Signal name/ listSPI0_CLK, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_IO2, SPI0_IO3, SPI0_CS[0:1]# (for flash), SPI0_CS2# (for TPM).

NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1 & Flash 2: 50 MHz. TPM & EC: 33 MHz.
Flash ProgrammerRequire additional isolation circuitry to protect CPU from back-feed voltage when connect to flash programmer.
EC and CPU branch requirementDelta between BO + M1 + M2 and M7 + M8 shall not exceed 12.7 mm.
Flash branch requirement, M3 + M4SPI branches of segment M3 + M4 need length matching within 2.54mm.
R1[1] DATA: 13 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 10.16 mm from the branch on SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3. [2] CLK: 24 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 10.16 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK.
R213 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R368 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Minimum length, total45.72 mm. Min length between CPU to the closest end device = 45.72 mm.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 1[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.45 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6.5 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 2[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.25 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 14 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 9 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.

SPI0 Flash 76.8MHz and 100MHz 1 to 3-Load Branch (Device Down) MAF Topology

SPI0 Flash 100MHz and 76.8MHz 1 Load (Device Down) MAF Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 100MHz and 76.8MHz 2 Load Branch (Device Down) MAF with Flash and TPM Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 100MHz and 76.8MHz 3 Load Branch (Device Down) MAF Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 76.8MHz and 100MHz 1 to 3-Load Branch (Device Down) MAF Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1: 100 MHz. TPM and Debug Tool: < 14.3 MHz.
Flash ProgrammerRequire additional isolation circuitry to protect CPU from back-feed voltage when connect to flash programmer.
R1[1] 22 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from flash device on SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3. [2] 10 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from flash device on SPI0_CLK.
R2430 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 2.54 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from CPU to Flash 1Length from CPU to flash 1: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4
Minimum length, totalBO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4 = 38.1 mm
Routing schemeInterleave 1 CS with every 2 DATA lanes is recommended. Recommend to route DATA and CLK on same layer.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 100MHz and 76.8MHz support[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 2 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 1.75 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 2 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Signal name/ listSPI0_CLK, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_IO2, SPI0_IO3, SPI0_CS0# (for flash), SPI0_CS2# (for TPM)

SPI0 Flash 76.8MHz and 100MHz 2 to 4-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Flash Sharing Topology

SPI0 Flash 100MHz and 76.8MHz 4 Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Flash Sharing Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 76.8MHz and 100MHz 2 to 4-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Flash Sharing Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1: 100 MHz. TPM and Debug Tool: < 14.3 MHz. EC: 50MHz.
R110 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm (100 MHz) & 15.24 mm (76.8 MHz) from flash device on SPI0_CLK. 16 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm (100 MHz) & 15.24 mm (76.8 MHz) from flash device on SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R2430 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 2.54 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from CPU to Flash 1Length from CPU to flash 1: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4
Minimum length, totalBO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4 = 30.48mm
Routing schemeInterleave 1 CS with every 2 DATA lanes is recommended. Recommend to route DATA and CLK on same layer.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 100MHz support[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 2 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 1.75 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 2 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 76.8MHz support[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 2 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 1.75 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 2 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
FET component criteriaRon < 4.5 Ω. Cin < 6 pF.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm

SPI0 Flash 50MHz 2-Load Branch (PCH.IOE to Flash and TPM) MAF Topology

SPI0 Flash 50MHz 2-Load Branch (PCH.IOE to Flash and TPM) MAF Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1: 50 MHz. TPM: 33 MHz.
Flash ProgrammerRequire additional isolation circuitry to protect CPU from back-feed voltage when connect to flash programmer.
R127 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 5.08 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R251 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 5.08 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from CPU to flash 1 or flash 2Length from CPU to flash 1: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 1[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.25 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 14 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 9 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 2[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.45 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6.5 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Minimum length, totalBO + M1 + M2 + M3 = 38.1 mm.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm

SPI0 Flash 66MHz and 100MHz 2-Load Branch (PCH.IOE to Flash and TPM) MAF Topology

SPI0 Flash 66 MHz and 100 MHz 2 Load Branch (Device Down) MAF Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 66MHz and 100MHz 2-Load Branch (PCH.IOE to Flash and TPM) MAF Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1: 100 MHz. TPM and Debug Tool: < 14.3 MHz.
Flash ProgrammerRequire additional isolation circuitry to protect CPU from back-feed voltage when connect to flash programmer.
R1[1] 20 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from flash device on SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3. [2] 10 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from flash device on SPI0_CLK.
R2430 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 5.08 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from CPU to Flash 1Length from CPU to flash 1: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3
Routing schemeInterleave 1 CS with every 2 DATA lanes is recommended. Recommend to route DATA and CLK on same layer.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 100 MHz and 66 MHz support[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 2 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 1.75 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 2 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Signal name/ listSPI0_CLK, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_IO2, SPI0_IO3, SPI0_CS0# (for flash), SPI0_CS2# (for TPM)
Max Number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias AllowedVia Placement
Rx, Tx5Total Channel

[For Internal Validation] SPI0 Flash 100MHz 4-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Isolation FET Topology

SPI0 Flash 100MHz 4 Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Isolation FET Flash Sharing Topology Diagram
[For Internal Validation] SPI0 Flash 100MHz 4-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Isolation FET Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1: 100 MHz. TPM and Debug Tool: < 14.3 MHz. EC: 50MHz.
R1[1] 9.1 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from flash device on SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3. [2] 0 Ω placeholder. To be placed within 12.7 mm from flash device on SPI0_CLK.
R2430 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 2.54 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R3Placeholder for PPV implementation. Unstuff by default.
R40 Ω. To be placed within 2.54 mm from the FET (for debug) on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R50 Ω. To be placed within 2.54 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from CPU to Flash 1Length from CPU to flash 1: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4
Minimum length, totalBO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4 = 40.64mm
Routing schemeInterleave 1 CS with every 2 DATA lanes is recommended. Recommend to route DATA and CLK on same layer.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 100MHz support[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.7 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 1.75 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 2 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
FET component criteriaRon < 4.5 Ω. Cin < 6 pF.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Signal name/ listSPI0_CLK, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_IO2, SPI0_IO3, SPI0_CS0# (for flash), SPI0_CS2# (for TPM)

SVID

SVID 1-Load (Device Down) Topology

SVID 1-Load (Device Down) Topology Diagram
SVID 1-Load (Device Down) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
VIDSOUT platform resistorsRpu1 = 160 Ω, Rpu2 = 160 Ω, R1 = 10 Ω, R2 = 10 Ω.
VIDSCK platform resistorsRpu1 = Empty, Rpu2 = 82 Ω, R1 = 0 Ω/ Short PAD, R2 = 15 Ω.
VIDSALERT# platform resistorsRpu1 = 100 Ω, Rpu2 = Empty, R1 = 0 Ω/ Short PAD, R2 = 0 Ω/ Short PAD.
Platform resistor tolerance± 5%
Clarification when Rpu1/ Rpu2/ R1/ R2 = Empty/ 0 Ω/ Short Pad[1] Rpu1 or Rpu2 = Empty; The specific side of the trace related to Rpu1 = Empty or Rpu2 = Empty does not need a pull-up resistor to the 1.25V power rail (VCCPRIM_IO_OUT_SVID). [2] R1 or R2 = 0 Ω/ Short Pad; The signal does not need a series resistor for the specific part on the trace which is being represented by R1 or R2. Be aware, the trace still needs to remain connected end to end. * It is strongly recommended to refer for the implementation on RVP.
Gen5 VRTT tool validation Stuff VIDSOUT R1 with 0 Ω if VIDSOUT signal swing fails VIL with Gen5 VRTT tool.
Maximum trace DC resistance 12 Ω
Signal PTH/ via transitionSuggest having a GND stitching vias for each signal transition. The GND stitching vias to the signal vias need to be within 5.08 mm from one another.
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Essential guidelines for routing near switching voltage regulator circuitIt is strongly recommended to meet routing near switching voltage regulator guidelines for SVID signals. Refer to "Switching VR Circuit Guideline" chapter in PDG for the details. (Technical White Paper Doc#:  726825)
Route orderingWhen routing at minimum spacing route ALERT between DATA and CLK.
Length matching between VIDSOUT and VIDSCK± 2.54 mm
Signal name/ listVIDSOUT, VIDSCK, VIDALERT#.
Max Number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias Allowed
Rx6
Tx6

SVID 2-Load Topology (Device Down) Diagram
SVID 2-Load (Device Down) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
VIDSOUT platform resistorsRpu1 = 160 Ω, Rpu2 = 160 Ω, R1 = 10 Ω, R2 = 10 Ω.
VIDSCK platform resistorsRpu1 = Empty, Rpu2 = 82 Ω, R1 = 0 Ω/ Short PAD, R2 = 50 Ω.
VIDSALERT# platform resistorsRpu1 = 100 Ω, Rpu2 = Empty, R1 = 220 Ω, R2 = 0 Ω/ Short PAD.
Platform resistor tolerance± 5%
Resistor Placement Recommendation (Rpu1, R1, Rpu2, R2)The Rpu1 & R1 resistor should be place close to CPU and Rpu2 & R2 resistor should be place close to IMVP.
Clarification when Rpu1/ Rpu2/ R1/ R2 = Empty/ 0 Ω/ Short Pad[1] Rpu1 or Rpu2 = Empty; The specific side of the trace related to Rpu1 = Empty or Rpu2 = Empty does not need a pull-up resistor to the 1.25V power rail (VCCPRIM_IO_OUT_SVID). [2] R1 or R2 = 0 Ω/ Short Pad; The signal does not need a series resistor for the specific part on the trace which is being represented by R1 or R2. Be aware, the trace still needs to remain connected end to end. * It is strongly recommended to refer for the implementation on RVP.

Maximum trace DC resistance 12 Ω
Signal PTH/ via transitionSuggest having a GND stitching vias for each signal transition. The GND stitching vias to the signal vias need to be within 5.08 mm from one another.
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Essential guidelines for routing near switching voltage regulator circuitIt is strongly recommended to meet routing near switching voltage regulator guidelines for SVID signals. Refer to "Switching VR Circuit Guideline" chapter in PDG for the details. (Technical White Paper Doc#:  726825)
Route orderingWhen routing at minimum spacing route Alert between Data and Clock.

THC-SPI

THC-SPI 1-Load (for Touch Panel) Topology

THC-SPI 1-Load (for Touch Panel) Topology Diagram
THC-SPI 1-Load (for Touch Panel) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency42.67 MHz (Please contact Intel for higher frequency enabling)
R118 Ω ± 5% To be placed 12.7 mm from the connector on THC[0:1]_SPI_CLK and THC[0:1]_SPI_IO[0:3].
M_cableRecommended to use shielded cable.
M_cable electrical characteristics-0.075 dB/inch < Insertion loss < -0.052 dB/inch -32.8 dB < Return loss < -46.2 dB -45.4 dB < Crosstalk < -47.2 dB 42 Ω < Impedance < 62 Ω
Minimum length, total 78.74 mm
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.125 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Devices Electrical AssumptionsPlease refer to "SPI Interface and Electrical Assumptions for the Touch Device" chapter in Intel Touch Host Controller Integration Guide for further detials. (Touch Integration Guide Doc#: 778513)
CPU buffer driver strength40 Ω.
Signal name/ listTHC0_SPI_CLK, THC0_SPI_IO[0:3], THC0_SPI_CS#, THC0_RST#, THC0_INT#, THC1_SPI_CLK, THC1_SPI_IO[0:3], THC1_SPI_CS#, THC1_RST#, THC1_INT#.

Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).

The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). XTAL

Crystal Oscillator Topology

38.4MHz Crystal Oscillator input
Crystal Oscillator Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Length matching between XTAL_IN and XTAL_OUTTotal length mismatch: 1.27 mm.
GND shieldingGND shielding to adjacent signals (especially high speed IO) is recommended.
Number of vias allowedMax 2 vias - recommended to minimize number of vias.
Main route (MR)Main route (MR) is recommended to be limited to SL/ DSL to limit coupling and impact from EMI/ RFI sources.
Reference planeContinuous GND only; do not reference to power planes. If routed as stripline or dual stripline, both top and bottom reference/ adjacent planes MUST be solid continuous ground. Avoid routing directly parallel (under/ over) to high current power planes. If unavoidable route signal orthogonal to power plane.
External capacitor valueExternal capacitors C1 and C2 must be matched (C1 = C2). Capacitors values should be tuned accordingly with respect to load capacitance for crystal. If the crystal load capacitance reduces (per component datasheet information), then C1/C2 should be reduced accordingly as well. Due to vendor variation in crystal characteristic, layout variation and PCB trace, calculation is recommended to determine the C1/C2 values.

Segment Lengths

Crystal Oscillator Topology Segment Lengths Routing Guidelines
SegmentTline TypeMax Length Segment (mm)
BOMS, SL
MRSL12.7

Max Length Total (mm): 25.4

(Validation) UFS Reference Clock

(Validation) UFS Reference Clock Topology

UFS Reference Clock Device Down Topology Diagram
UFS Reference Clock M.2 Connector Topology Diagram
(Validation) UFS Reference Clock Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Resistor values (for step down from 1.8 V to 1.2 V) R1 = 47 Ω R2 = 150 Ω To be placed within 25.4 mm to UFS device
Capacitor, CPlaceholder shunt capacitor (unstuff by default). To be placed near R1 Refer to EMC chapter in the PDG for more details
Platform resistor tolerance± 5%
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Microstrip routing limitationDue to potential RF interference concerns, it is recommended not to route UFS REFCLK signal on microstrip layer for the main route segment

Signal Group: Tx

EPD_ON Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Signal name/ listEPD_ON
Routing restrictionRoute the signal far away from the noisy source/signal. Refer to "Switching VR Circuit Guideline" chapter in PDG for the details. (Technical White Paper Doc#:  726825). Follow the small routing length as possible.
Package pinsEPD_ON_OUT, EPD_ON_IN

Routing restrictionRoute the signal far away from the noisy source/signal. Refer to "Switching VR Circuit Guideline" chapter in PDG for the details. (Technical White Paper Doc#:  726825). Follow the small routing length as possible.
Signal name/ listVDD2PWRGOOD
R0 Ω

EIO Flexi-PDG for I2C, SMLink

Description: EIO Flexi-PDG for I2C and SMLink

DDR5

SODIMM 1DPC

Pcb Type & Thickness: Type-3, 0.9mm

DDR5 SODIMM Type-3 10L Signals Topologies
DDR5 SODIMM Back-to-Back Placement Block Diagram
DDR5 SODIMM Side-by-Side Placement Block Diagram
DDR5 SODIMM 1DPC Top-Pin Bottom-Pin Definition and Compensation
SODIMM 1DPC Notes
NoteDetail
PCB stackupType-3 stackup with minimum of 8 layer.
Layer assignment rulesFollow the reference design (RVP).
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Number of vias allowedMax 2 transition vias.
Ground stitchingFor VSS stitching using microvia, target a minimum S:G ratio of 1:1 at signal layer transition. For VSS stitching using PTH, target a minimum S:G ratio of 2:1 at signal layer transition. VSS via stitching pattern to be copied exactly from RVP / clip files.
Max MS BO/ BI lengthRefer to RFI/ EMC guidelines for the max microstrip BO/ BI length requirement.
Serpentine routingUse 3x of dielectric height for serpentine routing spacing.
Bit/ Byte swapping ruleBit swapping is allowed within each Byte for all memory technologies. DDR5: Byte Swapping is allowed within each x32 channel.
MS BO and BI segment, PTH patternKeep DDR MS BO and BI as close as possible to reference board.
DDR to Non-DDR trace spacingMinimum 500 um.
Unused signalsDDR signals on CPU which are not applicable for DDR5 can be left unconnected (example ALERT).
Rtt/ Ctt for RESETKeep R1 empty; R2 = 0 Ohm; C1 = 0.1 uF (no stuff).
RCOMP value100 Ohm
CLK-to-CA/CS spacingOn L3 & L5, CLK & CA/CS may have a BO3 segment with CLK-to-CAC spacing of 375um after BO2
Max number of vias

CA, CLK, CS, DQ, DQS2

SODIMM 2DPC Tee ClamShell (B2B)

Pcb Type & Thickness: Type-3, 0.9mm

NVL_DDR5_Hx_2DPC_Topology_Diagram
Tee Clamshell Configuration
DDR5 SODIMM Top-Pin Bottom-Pin Length Propagation Definition
DDR5 SODIMM Top-Pin Bottom-Pin Length Propagation Compensation Requirements for Tee Clamshell Topology
SODIMM 2DPC Tee ClamShell (B2B) Notes
NoteDetail
PCB stackupMB Type-3 stackup with minimum 10-layers.
GND via placementFor Ch 0/1 CPU breakout, each DQ/ DQS signal via should have a GND via placed orthogonally next to it (within 800 um). DQ/ DQS signal vias from different bytes should be isolated from each other with a GND via.
GND via placementFor Ch 2/3 CPU breakout, each DQ/ DQS signal via should have a GND via placed orthogonally next to it (within 800 um). DQ/ DQS signal vias from different bytes should be isolated from each other with a GND via.
Reference planeContinuous Ground only.
Serpentine routingUse 3x of dielectric height for serpentine routing spacing.
Unused signalsUnused Data Mask pins on DIMMs should be tied to VSS supply. Only a minimal trace width is required to make ensure signal is terminated. A dedicated GND via is NOT recommended for the data mask pins.
Unused signalsUnused ECC/ CB and EVENT signals maybe left unconnected at the SODIMM connectors.
Unused signalsAlert is NOT recommended to be routed on customer boards. CPU Alert# pins should be left unconnected (i.e. no connect).
Routing"Group to Group" spacing in table above is referring to either DQ/ DQS to CLK/ CS/ CA within the same channel, or signals between different channels. DQ S2 and DQS S2 spacing refers DQ 2 DQS spacing.
RoutingKeep GND stitching via within 250 um from signal transition which changes reference planes.
RoutingFor both Channel 0/1 and 2/3, DQ and DQS signal vias for Segment E should be separated from each other with a GND via between.
RoutingIt is STRONGLY recommended customers follow the RVP board for DDR CPU BO region and via pattern at both CPU and DIMMs
Routing (voiding)Voiding of L2 under SODIMM connector DQ and DQS pins is NOT required for any channel in this topology.
Bit/Byte swapping ruleBit swapping is allowed within each Byte for all memory technologies. DDR5: Byte Swapping is allowed within each x32 channel. ECC bits swap is allowed within ECC byte / nibble: DDR5 ECC[3..0].
TuningChannel 0 and 1 are separate channels routing to the same DIMM. There is no explicit tuning relationship between these 2 channels. This also applies to Channel 2 and 3.
RESETKeep R1 empty; R2 = 0 Ohm; C1 = 0.1 uF (no stuff).
EMI/RFI mitigationWe recommend that in SODIMM 2DPC TEE Clamshell designs, the DIMMS that are on the inaccessible side of the mother board, i.e. the ones that would get populated first, 0R2R configuration, would use Rank 2, 3 for CS/CLK signals instead of Rank 0, 1 to mitigate the EMI/RFI risk.
Length compensation between top and bottom pinsFor any signal connected to a SODIMM right angle connector TOP side pin, increase the "effective" motherboard length of that signal by 3mm (~20ps) for the purposes of length matching rules. "Effective" length (for length matching) = motherboard length + 3mm. Designers should not just generically add 3mm of length directly to the physical motherboard signals connected to the TOP pin of a right angle SODIMM connector.
Include SODIMM connector top pin vs bottom pin compensation in length matchingRequired
Notes
NoteDetail
Region A Processor Break Out #1
Region B , B1, B2Processor Break Out #2
Region C, C1, C2Processor Break Out #3
Region D, D1, D2Main Segment from CPU to DIMM area.
Region E, E1, E2Layer 1 segment connecting to DIMM pin

LPDDR5/x

CAMM2 x128 Type-3

Pcb Type & Thickness: Type-3, 0.9mm

LPCAMM2 x128 Type-3 PCB DQ, DQS, CA, CS, CLK Topology Diagram
LPCAMM2 x128 Type-3 Reset and RCOMP Topology Diagram
LPCAMM2 x128 Type-3 CAMM Placement and Block Diagram
CAMM2 x128 Type-3 Notes
NoteDetail
LPCAMM2 connectorIntel recommends to follow the latest version LPCAMM2 connector CAD symbol from JEDEC Spec.
PCB stackupType-3 stackup with minimum of 10 layers.
Layer assignment rulesOuter Row DQ signals on Layer 3, Inner Row DQ Signals on Layer 5, DQS, WCK, CA, CS, CLK signals on Layer 7 and Layer 9. Follow the reference design (RVP).
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Number of vias allowedDQ/ RDQS/WCK CA/ CS/ CLK: Max 2 vias,
GND stitchingFor VSS stitching using microvia, target a minimum S:G ratio of 1:1 at signal layer transition. For VSS stitching using PTH, target a minimum S:G ratio of 2:1 at signal layer transition. VSS via stitching pattern to be copied exactly from RVP/ clip files.
Max MS BO/ BI lengthRefer to RFI/ EMC guidelines for the maximum microstrip BO/ BI length requirement.
Serpentine routingUse 3x of dielectric height for serpentine routing spacing.
WCK Tee-segment guidelineRoute with max differential impedance available; higher length helps reduce jitter, keep min 5 mm.
Bit/ Byte swapping ruleBit swapping is allowed within each Byte for all memory technologies. Byte swapping is allowed within a 16-bit channel. LPDDR5: x16 sub-channels can be swizzled within their x64 MC. When swapping channel DQ, the CA/CS signals must be swapped as well.
Unused signalsLeave unused DDR signals (PARITY, extra CA) floating (no connect). ALERT is also unused and can be left floating (no connect) at CPU side.
Rtt/ Ctt for RESETKeep R1 empty; R2 = 0 Ohm; C1 = 0.1 uF (no stuff).
RCOMP value100 Ohm
Max number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias Allowed
CA, CLK, CS, DQ, RDQS, WCK2

MD x32 Type-4

Pcb Type & Thickness: Type-4 2-x-2+, 0.8mm

LPDDR5/x x32 Type4 DQ, RDQS, WCK, CA, CS, CLK Topology Diagram
LPDDR5/x x32 Type-4 Reset and RCOMP Topology Diagram
LPDDR5_x x32 Type-4 Memory Down Placement and Block Diagram
MD x32 Type-4 Notes
NoteDetail
PCB stackupType-4 (2-x-2+) stackup with minimum of 10 layers.
Layer assignment rulesOuter row DQ on layer 2, Inner row DQ on layer 4, CAC can be on layer 6/8. Please follow RVP / Clip files for the layer assignment details.
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Number of vias allowedDQ/ RDQS/ WCK: max 2 vias ; Only micro-vias allowed. CA/ CS/ CLK: max 2 vias; Both micro-vias & PTH allowed.
GND stitchingFor VSS stitching using microvia, target a minimum S:G ratio of 1:1 at signal layer transition. For VSS stitching using PTH, target a minimum S:G ratio of 2:1 at signal layer transition. VSS via stitching pattern to be copied exactly from RVP / Clip files.
Serpentine routingUse 3x of dielectric height for serpentine routing spacing. Do not apply serpentine routing in the break-out region.
Bit/ Byte swapping ruleBit swapping is allowed within each Byte for all memory technologies. Byte swapping is allowed within a 16-bit channel. LPDDR5: x16 sub-channels can be swizzled within their x64 MC. When swapping channel DQ, the CA/CS signals must be swapped as well.
Unused signalsLeave unused DDR signals (PARITY, extra CA) floating (no connect). ALERT is also unused and can be left floating (no connect) at CPU side.
Rtt/ Ctt for RESETKeep R1 empty; R2 = 0 Ohm; C1 = 0.1 uF (no stuff).
RCOMP value100 Ohm
DDR to Non-DDR trace spacingMinimum 500 um.
Max number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias AllowedNotes
DQ, RDQS, WCK2Only Micro Vias allowed
CA, CLK, CS42 micro via and 2 PTH

EMC General Considerations

Ground Ring

PCB ground (GND) rings on all layers with GND PTH vias are recommended along the edge of the board. Multiple mounting holes should be used connecting the PCB GND to chassis ground. It can significantly reduce the PCB edge coupled noise.

Guidelines for PCB GND Ring and GND Stitching Vias

Multiple GND stitching vias are required on all mechanical mounting pads including for internal device modules (e.g. SSD, WiFi module) and I/O connectors (e.g. USB, DP) throughout the platform.

Ground Ring with Ground Vias

Connector Decoupling

Place a decoupling capacitor (0.1 uF, 0402 or smaller) on the power pins of all internal and external connectors to reduce power noise. These connectors include HDMI, DP, eDP, USB, Type C, FPC connectors, M.2, PCIe edge connector, etc.

Decoupling Capacitors Placement on Connector Power Pins

Crossing Splits in Reference Plane

Crossing a split in the reference plane increases emissions from signal traces. Avoid crossing plane splits by moving the traces or reshape the reference plane.

Avoid Signal Traces Routings Across Split Planes

Reference Discontinuity

Changing reference plane from GND to power plane, or from power plane A to power plane B, may significantly increase noise emission. It is recommended to have stitching capacitors (0.1 uF, 0402 or smaller) to bridge the two reference planes and provide current return path and the stitching capacitor must be placed as close as possible to the signal trace.

Reduce Signal Referencing Discontinuities Impact

Crystal RF Immunity

The crystal oscillator that provides the input clock to the CPU has been identified to be very sensitive to RF power from nearby radios. Radiated power from internal WWAN and WLAN antennas as well as from external WWAN/ WLAN devices placed near the platform can couple to the crystal and corrupt the clock signal causing issues such as screen flickering and system hang. Similarly, the crystal used with the Thunderbolt retimer is very sensitive to RF power, and noise from nearby antennas can result in connection loss with the device plugged into the Thunderbolt port. Refer to retimer collaterals in the EMC/RF Reference Documents section for XTAL specifications. The following RF Immunity Guidelines apply to both the 38.4 MHz crystal, RTC (real-time clock) crystal as well as the Thunderbolt retimer crystal.

  • Follow crystal routing guidelines very carefully. (Refer to Platform Clock Associated Signal Guidelines section).

  • Implement a ground ring surrounding crystal and related components. Refer to the figure below. Do not connect external load caps to GND ring, but rather directly to GND plane on adjacent layer.

  • Use a shielded crystal component.

  • Ensure that clock and high-speed I/O traces are not routed in proximity to the crystal components and traces (XTAL_IN/OUT).

  • Place crystal far away from antennas and potential RF power coupling paths such as unshielded/ungrounded cables. The exact distance needed depends on the platform design. Platforms without board shield may have higher risk.

  • Chassis shielding and design plays a critical role in RF immunity. Refer to the EMC Mechanical Considerations section and collateral #602554.

The following RF guidelines apply to RTC (real-time) crystal:

  • Reserve a placeholder for the RF cap on the power plane for RTC. The capacitance of the stuffed RF cap can be tuned with respect to the potential unintended RF power. The footprint should be as close as possible to CPU side.

RF Capacitor Placement Recommendation for RTC Crystal

Crystal Ground Ring Requirements

Adding a ground ring surrounding the crystal component, related components and routing can help reduce RF immunity risk.

Guidelines for Crystal Ground Ring Implementation and Components for RF Immunity

Memory RFI Mitigation

Memory interface and DRAM devices generate narrowband and broadband RFI noise. The noise may interfere with radio bands. The following guidelines help to reduce the RFI risk due to memory.

Memory RFI Mitigation Consideration

Design AreaWi-Fi only designsWi-Fi and WWAN/ 5G designs
Memory signals on Type-4 boardFully stripline required Fully stripline required
Memory signals main routing on Type-3 boardMain routing fully stripline requiredMain routing fully stripline required
Memory signals breakout routing on Type-3 boardDQ microstrip breakout signals <= 6.5 mm CLK, WCK, DQS, CA microstrip breakout signals <= 9 mmDQ microstrip breakout signals <= 6.5 mm CLK, WCK, DQS, CA microstrip breakout signals <= 9 mm
Memory device (SODIMM, solder down memory) shieldingRequired antenna distance needs to be considered based on system dependencyRequired antenna distance needs to be considered based on system dependency
Exposed memory power planes referenced to groundRF capacitors are recommendedRF capacitors are recommended
Exposed memory power planes referenced to memory signalsOn-board shield required and RF capacitors are requiredOn-board shield required and RF capacitors are required Additional RF capacitors for WWAN interfere frequencies may require
Memory Radio Frequency Interference Mitigation (RFIM) EnablingRecommended. Refer to Intel White Paper # 640438Recommended. Refer to Intel White Paper # 640438

Memory Signals Design Guidelines

It is recommended that DQ/ CLK/ DQS/ WCK/ CA signals are routed in inner layers, or the microstrip breakout trace length is required to be minimized as in the table below. An isolation ground guard ring is recommended on the surface layer between memory power plane and memory breakout signal routing.

Signal TypesTotal Microstrip Breakout Length (mm)
DQ<= 6.5
CLK, WCK, DQS, CA<= 9

* BI microstrip length should be ≤ 1.5 mm based on system dependency.

Memory Power Plane Routing Guidelines

It is recommended to embed memory power planes in inner PCB layers. If embedding memory power plane is not possible, please consider the following design guide:

When exposed memory power planes (VDD2/VDDQ) are referenced to solid GND, and memory data rate falls into Wi-Fi 2.4 GHz/ 5 GHz/ 6 GHz and WWAN radio bands, exposed memory power planes can radiate narrowband RFI noise at data rate frequency.

  • It is recommended to add platform RF capacitors to mitigate power plane noise (refer to exposed memory Power plane RF capacitors decoupling below).

  • It is recommended to shield exposed memory power planes or add absorber.

  • If data rate does not fall into radio bands, the platform RF capacitors guideline can be optional.

When exposed memory power planes are referenced to memory signals, exposed memory power planes can radiate both narrowband and broadband RFI noise.

  • Required platform RF capacitors to mitigate power plane noise (refer to exposed memory power plane RF Capacitor placement as below).

  • Required shielding on exposed memory power planes or add absorber.

  • Highly recommended avoiding surface memory power plane reference to memory signal, instead, surface memory power planes shall be referenced to solid GND plane in adjacent layer.

RFI Suppression Guidelines on Memory Signal and Power Plane Exposure
Exposed Memory Power Plane RF Decoupling Capacitors

Memory power plane could be shared or separated based on design configuration.

RF decoupling capacitors are paired in groups.

  • 0402 12 pF and 0402 2.2 pF

  • 0201 15 pF and 0201 3.0 pF

RF decoupling capacitors pairs placement.

  • < 4 mm proximity from CPU and memory devices

  • Pair-to-pair distance < 12 mm.

  • Evenly distributed.

Memory Devices

Memory devices (ex. DRAM, SODIMM, LPCAMM2) can radiate broadband and narrowband RFI noise and may cause radio frequency interference. A combination of EMI shield and antenna placement is one of the solutions to mitigate noise from memory devices.

SODIMM memory devices can cause higher RFI noise than the soldered down DRAM devices and it is recommended to use an EMI shield for the SODIMM memory devices and/or use the DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) feature.

Refer to the sections “On-Board Shielding” and “Intel DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) Software Feature” for more information.

LPCAMM2 PCB Design Guidelines

1) Avoid exposed power planes

Avoid exposed memory power plane on top and bottom side of motherboard. Distribute GND stitching vias across the GND plane.

Avoid Exposed Memory Power Plane on Top and Bottom Side of Motherboard

2) LPCAMM2 back plate grounding and module retention screws

For improved RFI performance, it is recommended to ensure a ground connection between the LPCAMM2 module and the PCB.

  • Expose ground pads with multiple ground stitching vias around mechanical mounting/screw holes on the bottom side of the motherboard PCB (to allow ground contact of the back plate).

  • A back plate with a custom nut (or EMI washer, alternatively) is recommended to ensure ground connection between back plate and PCB bottom layer ground.

  • The recommended back plate and threaded insert/custom nut dimensions are the following figure (in mm).

  • Conductive screws without any coating/paint are recommended to secure the module to the motherboard. The screw's dimensions guidelines (in mm) are based on a recommended LPCAMM2 module-level shield.

Provide solder mask opening for GND (VSS) around mounting holes
Back plate with threaded insert or nut for ground contact to PCB
Recommended LPCAMM2 module screw dimensions

3) LPCAMM2 Module-level Shield

A module-level EMI shield can be installed on the LPCAMM2 module as illustrated in the pictures below. The shield must make ground contact to the ground ring on the periphery of the module. A top plate/EMI shield with conductive foam gaskets can be used to achieve the ground contact of the shield with the module PCB. The figures below show the recommended dimensions for the shield and conductive gaskets.

Optional on-module shield for LPCAMM2
Recommended dimensions for LPCAMM2 on-module shield
Critical dimensions for conductive gasket for LPCAMM2 on-module shield

Intel DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) Software Feature

DDR RFIM is a frequency-shifting RFI-mitigation software feature.  The DDR RFIM feature is primarily aimed at resolving narrowband RFI from memory (DDR and LPDDR technologies and both soldered-down and modules) for the Wi-Fi in high frequency bands (5 to 7GHz). By changing the DDR data rate, using Intel dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS) technology, the narrowband memory noise at the clock harmonic frequency can be shifted out of a radio band of interest, thus mitigating RFI to the radio. The change of the DDR data rate is dynamic based on the radio channel in use.

Dynamic DDR data rate selection and control can be done at the request of the Intel integrated Wi-Fi firmware (CNVi) or at the request of Intel’s DTT DDR RFIM policy. In systems with CNVi installed, the feature is enabled by default. In systems with discrete Intel or 3rd party Wi-Fi, the DDR RFIM policy must be enabled in DTT. For both cases, the OEM has the option to customize the DDR RFI table (list of Wi-Fi channels affected by each DDR frequency of the system) based on the measured platform noise.

Intel also offers a semiautomatic tool to characterize the platform DDR noise and customize the DDR RFI table that is an input to RFIM. It is highly recommended to use the tool to characterize the noise from the different memory DVFS points. Refer to white papers #640438 and #816192 for detailed information.

DLVR RFI Design Guidelines

The Digital Linear Voltage Regulator (DLVR) may induce RF noise on input power planes / rails that couple to radio antennas, resulting in RF interference within radio bands.

The following guidelines help to reduce the RFI risk due to DLVR.

Minimize DLVR Input Power Planes’ Exposure

It is recommended that the DLVR input power plane (VCCCORE) size be minimized on surface layers while considering PI requirements. Refer to power integrity requirement for resistance and VR sense feedback recommendations.

RF Decoupling Capacitors on DLVR Input Power Planes

High-frequency decoupling capacitors on the DLVR input power plane(s) can help in DLVR noise-reduction. Since there are system-level dependencies for the RFI, in certain scenarios (like a system with aggressive antenna placement to DLVR input power plane or WWAN radio), it is recommended to have placeholders for decoupling capacitors. The following table and figures show the recommended values and placement for the decoupling capacitors and an example of layout implementation.

RF Decoupling Capacitor Guideline for DLVR
Example of RF Cap Placement for DLVR power plane

NPU and GPU Power Planes RFI Design Guidelines

The Neural Processing Unit (NPU) and Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) may induce RF noise on power planes / rails that couple to radio antennas, resulting in RF interference within radio bands.

The following guidelines help to reduce the RFI risk due to NPU and GPU power planes.

RF Decoupling Capacitors on NPU and GPU Power Planes

It is recommended to have placeholders for high-frequency decoupling capacitors on the VCCSA (NPU power plane) and VCCGT (GPU power plane). These decoupling capacitors may help in reducing potential NPU and GPU noise in certain scenarios such as a system with aggressive antenna placement to NPU and GPU power planes. The following table and figure show the recommended values and placement for the decoupling capacitors:

RF Decoupling Capacitor Guideline for NPU and GPU Power Planes
Case #Location of Decoupling Capacitor Capacitance for 2.4GHz BandComments$[internal]Cap Stuffing Option for Internal Validation
Case: 1Directly underneath pair of NPU / GPU and GND vias (Directly from BGAs) on the plane6 x 8.2pF (0402 size) or 6 x 10pF (0201 size)Preferred placement for RF decoupling capacitors. Capacitors are recommended to be placed directly underneath the pair of NPU / GPU - GND vias at bottom layer or at least within the CPU's shadow area.Stuffed
Case: 2< 5mm from NPU / GPU BGA routed with short trace6 x capacitors (expected <= 8.2pF for 0402 size, value is layout dependent)Due to trace parasitic, the capacitance value may need to be tuned based on specific layoutStuffed
Case: 3> 5mm away from NPU / GPU BGANot recommendedRF capacitors are NOT effective for RFI reduction in this location of placementStuffed

HSIO RFI Mitigation

Exposed high speed I/O routing traces are considered as RF interference source. The RF interference level depends on interface signal characteristics such as data rate and distance between antenna and signal trace.

Minimize Exposed High Speed I/O Channel Routing

It is recommended that the routing of I/O interfaces in the table below be embedded in inner layers and covered by solid ground. Due to routing limitations, full stripline routing may not be possible at breakout and the routing at the connector region. Refer to the table below for maximum microstrip length.

InterfaceData RateMax Breakout Length (Microstrip)Max Routing Length at Connector Region (Microstrip)Cable ShieldingNote
eUSB2 480 Mbps < 38 mm < 25 mm Shielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
UFS reference clock 38.4MHz < 38 mm < 25 mm Shielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax Add a placeholder shunt capacitor (0402 or 0201 size) near to UFS device. Refer to UFS Reference Clock PDG chapter for more information about capacitor placement.
UFS 4.0 Gear 5 20 Gbps (Rate A), 23.32 Gbps (Rate B) < 38 mm < 25 mm Shielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
CNVio3 (STEP)12 GbpsRefer to CNVio3 subsection (under High Speed chapter CNVio Bus section)Refer to CNVio3 subsection (under High Speed chapters CNVio Bus section)Not applicableKeep out distance of CNVio3 signals (microstrip) to Wi-Fi antenna > 15 mm. Refer to Intel document #610694 for the latest Intel Wi-Fi module RFI/EMC recommendations.

HDMI 2.112 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax

PCIe532 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ CoaxRefer to PCIe Gen5 Add-in Card Clock Topology or PCIe Gen5 Device Down Clock Topology (under High Speed I/Os and PCH I/Os chapter) for more EMC/ RF noise protection recommendations.
PCIe Differential Clock100 MHz< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ CoaxRefer to PCIe Gen4/Gen5 Add-in Card Clock Topology or PCIe Gen4/Gen5 Device Down Clock Topology (under High Speed I/Os chapter) for more EMC/ RF noise protection recommendations.
SPI Clk< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
TCP USB+DP10 and 20 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
TCP TBT520 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
USB2.0480 Mbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
USB3.2 Gen15 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
USB3.2 Gen210 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax

For HSIO cable and connector information, refer to EMC Mechanical Considerations section.

eDP RFI Mitigation

RF Interference from Embedded Display Port (eDP) Interface and TCON

In designs with small form factors, RF interference from eDP interface has become more problematic due to the increase of thinner and lighter devices, which limit options for effective cable shielding and antenna isolation. While the data rates increase, the high-frequency data and clocks generate RF noise that falls into Wi-Fi radio bands. Besides RF noise from eDP, timing controller (TCON), used to convert the eDP signal and drive the individual pixels of the display, could be another source of interference.

Narrowband Spur Noise from eDP Data and TCON Clock

To prevent interference with radio bands, select the eDP data rates that ensure the fundamental frequencies and harmonics of the eDP signals do not fall into Wi-Fi radio bands. The data rates 2.43 Gbps and 6.75 Gbps should be avoided to mitigate the RF noise impact on Wi-Fi radios. Hence, display panels supporting 2.7/8.1 Gbps should be chosen. Other mitigation solutions such as using high-quality shielding cable for eDP and TCON connection/board or enabling spread spectrum clocking may provide effective but limited noise reduction as an alternative solution.

Mitigate RF interference by preventing using data rate falling into Wi-Fi radios
TCON clock noise falling into Wi-Fi bands

eUSB2V2 (Internal Validation)

It is recommended that eUSB2V2 routing be embedded in inner layers and covered by solid ground. Due to routing limitations, full stripline routing may not be possible at breakout region and the routing at the connector region. Please refer to the table below for maximum microstrip length.

InterfaceMax Routing Length at Breakout Region (Microstrip)Max Routing Length at Connector Region (Microstrip)Cable Shielding
eUSB2V2< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax

EMC Component Selection

Common Mode Choke Selection

The common mode choke (CMC) selection is shown below. Alternatively, PCB CMC can be also considered for DP 1.4, DP 2.0, eDP, TCP USB+DP (10 Gbps), USB 3.2 Gen 1 and USB3.2 Gen2 signal. Refer to Intel document #546122 for Intel PCB Common Mode Choke License Technology Technical White Paper.

InterfaceData RateCMC PlacementCMC Cutoff Frequency (3-dB Bandwidth)CMC Insertion LossCM Rejection (10-dB Band)$[internal] Reference Part
DP8.1 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>10 GHz< 1.2 dB @ 5 GHz1.8-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2
DP10 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>10 GHz< 1.2 dB @ 5 GHz1.8-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2
DP20 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>10 GHz< 0.62 dB @ 10GHz1.8-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB542HS2
eDP8.1 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector> 10 GHz< 1.2 dB @ 5 GHz1.8 - 3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2
HDMI 2.1< 6 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>6 GHz< 0.8 dB @1.5 GHz / < 1.5 dB @3.0 GHz0.3-3.8 GHzDLM0QSB350HY2
HDMI 2.112 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>10 GHz< 1.0 dB @ 6 GHz0.3-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2
USB2.0*480 Mb/s<25 mm routing length from connector< 0.2 dB @240 MHz0.5-2.0 GHzDLW21SN900SQ2L
eUSB2.0* 480 Mb/s <25 mm routing length from connector   <0.2 dB @240 MHz 0.5-2.0 GHz DLW21SN900SQ2L 
USB3.2 Gen 15 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>7.5 GHz< 1.5 dB @2.5 GHz1.8-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2
USB3.2 Gen 210 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>10 GHz< 1.2 dB @ 5 GHz1.8-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2

* Common mode chokes with a target common mode impedance of 80 to 90 Ohm at 100 MHz generally provide adequate noise attenuation for USB 2.0 and eUSB 2.0.

Higher impedance CMC generally have a greater damaging effect on signal quality. Signal quality must be checked for low-speed, full-speed and high-speed USB operations in case high impedance component is used.

CMC Placement Guideline for USB3 Interface

Port Usage ScenarioCMC Guideline
USB3 onlyPlace Tx CMCs; Rx CMCs are optional
USB3 & DPPlace both Tx and Rx CMCs due to emission from DP
USB3 & TBTDo not place either Tx or Rx CMCs

ESD Diode Selection

ESD diode selection recommendations below only apply to interfaces with:

  • Hotplug input/output port application (external ports that exposed to end user)

  • Direct connection between SOC and connector (Eg, without redriver / retimer in between)

For interfaces that require retimer:

  • Intel retimer: Refer to Thunderbolt retimer or controller documentation for more details, document number can be found in PDG chapter “EMC/RF Reference Documents”.

  • Third party retimer: Customer may contact vendor for necessary ESD protection.

For further ESD design optimization, customers may refer to Chapter “System Efficient ESD Design (SEED)” for more details.

InterfaceData Rate ESD Diode PlacementESD Diode Shunt CapacitanceESD Diode RdynESD Diode Reverse Working Voltage$[internal]Reference Part
HDMI 2.1 Direct Connect Rate ≤ 6 Gbps (Data)≤ 6 Gbps  < 25 mm routing length from connector  < 0.4 pF  < 0.5 Ohm  4.0 V PESD4V0Z1BSF 
HDMI 2.1 Direct Connect Rate > 6Gbps (Data)> 6 Gbps  < 25 mm routing length from connector  < 0.4 pF  < 0.5 Ohm  4.0 V PESD4V0Z1BSF 
HDMI connector HPD/DDC pins   < 25 mm routing length from connector        5.0 V  PESD5V0H1BSF  
USB2.0480 Mbps  < 25 mm routing length from connector  < 1.5 pF  < 0.8 Ohm  5.5 V  ESD131-B1-W0201  
USB3.2 Gen1/2 Type A ≤ 10 Gbps  < 25 mm routing length from connector  < 0.35 pF  < 0.5 Ohm  3.3 V  PESD3V3Z1BSF  

Other Component Selection

The AC cap needs to be next to the connector and followed by ESD diode. Refer to SI PDG for values/placement.

Switching Voltage regulators can show broadband noise in the LTE low band, adding ferrite bead can help in reducing the noise.
